para.sentence: With \gamma and \Gamma denoting here the general values of the incomplete gamma functions (§8.2(i)), we define \mathrm{ci}\left(a,z\right)\pm i\mathrm{si}\left(a,z\right)=e^{\pm\frac{1}{2} \pi ia}\Gamma\left(a,ze^{\mp\frac{1}{2}\pi i}\right), , \mathrm{Ci}\left(a,z\right)\pm i\mathrm{Si}\left(a,z\right)=e^{\pm\frac{1}{2} \pi ia}\gamma\left(a,ze^{\mp\frac{1}{2}\pi i}\right).

From §§8.2(i) and 8.2(ii) it follows that each of the four functions \mathrm{si}\left(a,z\right) , \mathrm{ci}\left(a,z\right) , \mathrm{Si}\left(a,z\right) , and \mathrm{Ci}\left(a,z\right) is a multivalued function of z with branch point at z=0.

Furthermore, \mathrm{si}\left(a,z\right) and \mathrm{ci}\left(a,z\right) are entire functions of a , and \mathrm{Si}\left(a,z\right) and \mathrm{Ci}\left(a,z\right) are meromorphic functions of a with simple poles at a=-1,-3,-5,\dots and a=0,-2,-4,\dots , respectively.

When \operatorname{ph}z=0 (and when a\neq-1,-3,-5,\dots , in the case of \mathrm{Si}\left(a,z\right) , or a\neq 0,-2,-4,\dots , in the case of \mathrm{Ci}\left(a,z\right) ) the principal values of \mathrm{si}\left(a,z\right) , \mathrm{ci}\left(a,z\right) , \mathrm{Si}\left(a,z\right) , and \mathrm{Ci}\left(a,z\right) are defined by (8.21.1) and (8.21.2) with the incomplete gamma functions assuming theirprincipal values (§8.2(i)).
Elsewhere in the sector |\operatorname{ph}z|\leq\pi the principal values are defined by analytic continuation from \operatorname{ph}z=0 ; compare §4.2(i).

From here on it is assumed that unless indicated otherwise the functions \mathrm{si}\left(a,z\right) , \mathrm{ci}\left(a,z\right) , \mathrm{Si}\left(a,z\right) , and \mathrm{Ci}\left(a,z\right) have their principal values.

Properties of the four functions that are stated below in §§8.21(iii) and 8.21(iv) follow directly from the definitions given above, together with properties of the incomplete gamma functions given earlier in this chapter.

In the case of §8.21(iv) the equation \int_{0}^{\infty}t^{a-1}e^{\pm\mathrm{i}t}\mathrm{d}t=e^{\pm\frac{1}{2}\pi \mathrm{i}a}\Gamma\left(a\right), if 0<\Re a<1, (obtained from (5.2.1) by rotation of the integration path) is also needed.

\mathrm{si}\left(a,z\right)=\int_{z}^{\infty}t^{a-1}\sin t\mathrm{d}t, if \Re a<1, , \mathrm{ci}\left(a,z\right)=\int_{z}^{\infty}t^{a-1}\cos t\mathrm{d}t, if \Re a<1, , \mathrm{Si}\left(a,z\right)=\int_{0}^{z}t^{a-1}\sin t\mathrm{d}t, if \Re a>-1, , \mathrm{Ci}\left(a,z\right)=\int_{0}^{z}t^{a-1}\cos t\mathrm{d}t, if \Re a>0.
In these representations the integration paths do not cross the negative real axis, and in the case of (8.21.4) and (8.21.5) the paths also exclude the origin.

\mathrm{Si}\left(a,z\right)=\Gamma\left(a\right)\sin\left(\tfrac{1}{2}\pi a \right)-\mathrm{si}\left(a,z\right), if a\neq-1,-3,-5,\dots, \mathrm{Ci}\left(a,z\right)=\Gamma\left(a\right)\cos\left(\tfrac{1}{2}\pi a \right)-\mathrm{ci}\left(a,z\right), if a\neq 0,-2,-4,\dots.
\mathrm{si}\left(0,z\right)=-\mathrm{si}\left(z\right),\mathrm{ci}\left(0,z\right)=-\mathrm{Ci}\left(z\right), \mathrm{Si}\left(0,z\right)=\mathrm{Si}\left(z\right).
For the functions on the right-hand sides of (8.21.10) and (8.21.11) see §6.2(ii).

\mathrm{Si}\left(a,\infty\right)=\Gamma\left(a\right)\sin\left(\tfrac{1}{2}\pi a \right), if a\neq-1,-3,-5,\dots, , \mathrm{Ci}\left(a,\infty\right)=\Gamma\left(a\right)\cos\left(\tfrac{1}{2}\pi a \right), if a\neq 0,-2,-4,\dots.

\mathrm{Si}\left(a,z\right)=z^{a}\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}\frac{(-1)^{k}z^{2k+1}}{(2 k+a+1)(2k+1)!}, if a\neq-1,-3,-5,\dots, \mathrm{Ci}\left(a,z\right)=z^{a}\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}\frac{(-1)^{k}z^{2k}}{(2k+ a)(2k)!}, if a\neq 0,-2,-4,\dots.

\mathrm{Si}\left(a,z\right)=z^{a}\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}\frac{\left(2k+\frac{3}{2} \right){\left(1-\frac{1}{2}a\right)_{k}}}{{\left(\frac{1}{2}+\frac{1}{2}a \right)_{k+1}}}\mathsf{j}_{2k+1}\left(z\right), if a\neq-1,-3,-5,\dots, , \mathrm{Ci}\left(a,z\right)=z^{a}\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}\frac{\left(2k+\frac{1}{2} \right){\left(\frac{1}{2}-\frac{1}{2}a\right)_{k}}}{{\left(\frac{1}{2}a\right) _{k+1}}}\mathsf{j}_{2k}\left(z\right), if a\neq 0,-2,-4,\dots.
For \mathsf{j}_{n}\left(z\right) see §10.47(ii).
For (8.21.16), (8.21.17), and further expansions in series of Bessel functions see Luke (1969b, pp. 56–57).
f(a,z)=\mathrm{si}\left(a,z\right)\cos z-\mathrm{ci}\left(a,z\right)\sin z, , g(a,z)=\mathrm{si}\left(a,z\right)\sin z+\mathrm{ci}\left(a,z\right)\cos z.
\mathrm{si}\left(a,z\right)=f(a,z)\cos z+g(a,z)\sin z, , \mathrm{ci}\left(a,z\right)=-f(a,z)\sin z+g(a,z)\cos z.
When |\operatorname{ph}z|<\pi and \Re a<1 , f(a,z)=\int_{0}^{\infty}\frac{\sin t}{(t+z)^{1-a}}\mathrm{d}t, g(a,z)=\int_{0}^{\infty}\frac{\cos t}{(t+z)^{1-a}}\mathrm{d}t.

When |\operatorname{ph}z|<\frac{1}{2}\pi , f(a,z)=\frac{z^{a}}{2}\int_{0}^{\infty}\left((1+it)^{a-1}+(1-it)^{a-1}\right)e ^{-zt}\mathrm{d}t, g(a,z)=\frac{z^{a}}{2i}\int_{0}^{\infty}\left((1-it)^{a-1}-(1+it)^{a-1}\right) e^{-zt}\mathrm{d}t.

When z\to\infty with |\operatorname{ph}z|\leq\pi-\delta ( <\pi ), f(a,z)\sim z^{a-1}\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}\frac{(-1)^{k}{\left(1-a\right)_{2k}}}{z^ {2k}}, , g(a,z)\sim z^{a-1}\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}\frac{(-1)^{k}{\left(1-a\right)_{2k+1}}}{ z^{2k+1}}.
For the corresponding expansions for \mathrm{si}\left(a,z\right) and \mathrm{ci}\left(a,z\right) apply (8.21.20) and (8.21.21).
